title: The Best And Worst Biceps Exercises

S-Tier.setup_notes: Angle your upper arm on a preacher bench.
S-Tier.execution_notes: Go all the way down to achieve a good stretch. The setup locks your elbows in place, making it nearly impossible to cheat.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Provides high tension, especially in the stretched position. High tension in the stretched position is more important than the total stretch a muscle experiences. Locks elbows, preventing cheating, which ensures all tension is directed to the biceps. Feels good with a smooth resistance profile.
S-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Distal biceps (closer to the elbow joint).
S-Tier.scientific_insights: A recent study compared incline curls to preacher curls, showing that the preacher curl caused significantly more distal biceps growth. This is most likely because with the preacher curl, you get very high tension in a pretty good stretch, whereas with the incline curl, you get basically no tension in a very big stretch.
S-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff cannot find anything to criticize about this exercise.

S-Tier.execution_notes: The machine provides a locked-in movement. Jeff specifically performs these only in the bottom half of the range of motion to emphasize the stretch more.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Offers the added benefit of being nice and locked in, allowing for consistent tension and form. Allows for emphasis on the stretched position.
S-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff includes these every single week in his routine. While S-tier, it is not his number one bicep builder.

S-Tier.exercise_name: Face Away Cable Curl (Beian Cable Curl)
S-Tier.setup_notes: Flip around and face away from the cable machine. Set the cable at approximately hand height. Take one or two steps forward.
S-Tier.execution_notes: Curl with both arms at the same time. If a dual-stack cable machine is not available, perform one arm at a time.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Immediately improves the tension profile by placing the arms back behind the torso, which provides maximum stretch on the biceps. Maintains a nice, even tension throughout the entire range of motion. Provides high tension in the stretched position.
S-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Long head of the biceps, as it experiences a very high degree of stretch and tension.
S-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff considers this exercise amazing and recommends definitely including it if you are trying to bring up your biceps peak. He considers it the best of the best bicep exercise, with the 45-degree preacher curl being a very close second.

S-Tier.execution_notes: Perform hammer curls (neutral grip, thumb up) while braced against the preacher bench.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Instantly improves the resistance profile of hammer curls by providing a stable, braced position. This allows for better tension throughout the range of motion, especially in the stretched position.
S-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Biceps Peak, due to the emphasis on the brachialis muscle.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Use the outer part of the easy bar for a shoulder-width grip.
A-Tier.execution_notes: The grip angle is in between a fully supinated grip (like a barbell curl) and a neutral grip (like a hammer curl). To ensure the biceps are still firing despite the angled grip, think about driving through your pinkies as you curl.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Eases torque on the wrists compared to a straight barbell. Good for overload and can be used as a heavy free-weight bicep movement in the 6-8 rep range. Convenient, simple, and allows for progressive overload.
A-Tier.target_muscle_parts: The angled grip might shift some tension toward the brachialis and brachioradialis instead of the biceps per se, but this can be mitigated with proper cues.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff frequently includes this exercise in his routine due to its convenience, simplicity, and overload potential, bumping it up from an optimization standpoint of B-tier to A-tier.

A-Tier.execution_notes: Perform curls with dumbbells. It is recommended to do both arms at the same time for optimal muscle growth.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Convenient exercise that will still grow your arms. Allows for working each side individually, which can help fix bicep size asymmetries. However, it loses a point for a suboptimal tension curve.
A-Tier.limitations: Has zero tension in the full stretch, similar to barbell and easy bar curls. Doing alternating dumbbell curls might be slightly less optimal due to the long rest in between each rep.
A-Tier.scientific_insights: A study from Goto and colleagues suggests that long pauses without any tension in between reps are probably worse for muscle growth. Jeff notes that a new study on full range of motion versus lengthened partials in experienced trainees has influenced his perspective on the importance of tension at full stretch.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff would have emphasized the suboptimal tension curve more before the new study on full range of motion versus lengthened partials.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Perform curls on an incline bench.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: A solid lengthened-biased movement that is fast to set up and easy to do. However, a study showed it to be worse than preacher curls for distal biceps growth.
A-Tier.limitations: Experiences basically no tension in a very big stretch.
A-Tier.scientific_insights: A study comparing incline curls to preacher curls showed that preacher curls caused significantly more distal biceps growth. This is likely because incline curls get basically no tension in a very big stretch, despite the large stretch.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff still performs these from time to time.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Lie down to perform the curl.
A-Tier.execution_notes: This variation provides a huge stretch, especially near the top of the bicep close to the shoulder. When lying down, more tension is felt in the biceps in the most stretched starting position compared to an incline curl.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: An extreme version of the incline curl that provides a huge stretch and more tension in the most stretched position compared to the standard incline curl.
A-Tier.limitations: May not be suitable for individuals with shoulder issues.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff first saw Dr. Mike perform these and found them to feel solid. While it's too early for him to definitively say if he prefers them over standard incline curls, he definitely thinks they are worth trying out.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Start seated for the first seven reps, then stand for the next seven, and remain standing for the final seven.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Perform seven seated curls first, which train the shortened top half of the range of motion. Then, stand up and do seven full range of motion curls. Finally, perform seven bottom-half curls, emphasizing the lengthened position. For the final set, continue past seven reps until you can no longer get at least halfway up.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: This modified order (short, then full, then long) is considered smarter because the curls get a little easier as the biceps fatigue, and the set ends with a focus on length-biased partials, which are highly anabolic.
A-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Emphasizes both shortened and lengthened positions of the biceps.
A-Tier.alternative_options: Traditional 21s (considered high C-tier due to suboptimal rep order).
A-Tier.additional_notes: Doing the initial curls seated helps standardize the range of motion on each rep and keeps the exercise more interesting.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Position your arms at your sides.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Provides nice, even tension throughout the entire range of motion. Considered good, but not great, due to the lack of a significant pre-stretch in the biceps.
A-Tier.limitations: Does not provide a big pre-stretch in the biceps.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff includes these periodically in his routine.

A-Tier.exercise_name: Freaky Looking Variation of Beian Cable Curl
A-Tier.setup_notes: Requires finding the correct cable height to achieve a 90-degree angle between the cable and your forearm.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Perform the curl ensuring a 90-degree angle between the cable and your forearm while the bicep is in its most stretched position.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Achieves maximum tension on the biceps while they are in their most stretched position, which is highly beneficial for muscle growth.
A-Tier.limitations: Can be awkward the first time it's attempted until the correct cable height is found.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff has only had this variation in his rotation for about a month. While he feels it's S-tier, he is tentatively placing it in A-tier to avoid overhyping it too early.

A-Tier.execution_notes: Use a little momentum to help get the weight moving during the concentric (lifting) phase. Crucially, resist and control the load on the very anabolic negative (lowering) phase.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Allows for curling a bit more load, which can then be controlled during the anabolic negative phase. Can be effective for biceps growth and can teach experienced trainees to push themselves harder.
A-Tier.limitations: Not recommended for beginners. The cheating must be controlled, and the negative phase must be resisted properly.
A-Tier.scientific_insights: There are currently no studies on whether cheating or strict form causes more muscle growth, though Jeff plans to help run such a study soon. Theoretically, both approaches have merits.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff believes a properly executed cheat curl can be great for biceps growth for experienced trainees, as long as the negative is controlled and the cheating is kept in check.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Brace against a wall with three points of contact: your glutes, your upper back, and your head.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Maintain very strict technique throughout the movement.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Directs all tension from the bar directly into the biceps, unlike cheat curls where tension can be lost to the hips or lower back. Provides a clear progression path: if you're lifting more weight or doing more reps, your biceps are getting stronger and likely bigger.
A-Tier.scientific_insights: There are currently no studies comparing strict curls to cheat curls, making it difficult to definitively say which is better for muscle growth.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff suspects strict curls would be slightly better than cheat curls, but without a study, it's hard to know for sure, and he acknowledges it could go either way.

A-Tier.execution_notes: Use a neutral grip, pointing your thumb up. This grip takes your biceps out of supination.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: By taking the biceps out of supination, tension is shifted away from the biceps and toward the brachialis. Growing the brachialis can push the biceps up, enhancing the appearance of the biceps peak.
A-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Biceps Peak, as the brachialis muscle, which sits underneath the biceps, becomes very active and can push the biceps up, creating bigger peaks.
A-Tier.limitations: Has the same tension issue as all free-weight standing curls, meaning zero tension in the full stretch.
A-Tier.scientific_insights: While there is no hard science on changing the genetic structure of biceps or directly proving brachialis growth enhances peak, it makes theoretical sense that a larger brachialis would contribute to a more peaked bicep shape.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff considers hammer curls his number one movement for biceps peak.

A-Tier.execution_notes: Perform a hammer curl (neutral grip) on the positive (concentric) phase, and then transition to a standard supinated curl on the negative (eccentric) phase.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Combines the advantages of both hammer curls (for brachialis emphasis on the positive) and supinated curls (for biceps emphasis on the negative). Allows for overloading the biceps on the negative phase with a bit more load, as you can generally curl more weight up with a hammer grip, and the biceps are stronger on the negative.
A-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Emphasizes the brachialis on the concentric and the biceps on the eccentric.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff considers this a smart pairing of movements.

B-Tier.tier_reasons: Very good for overload, allowing for easy addition of weight or reps over time. However, tension on the bicep is not optimal, with the hardest part of the range at 90 degrees and zero tension at full stretch. The straight barbell can also put strain on the wrists.
B-Tier.limitations: Suboptimal tension profile (zero tension at full stretch). Straight barbell can cause wrist strain. Using a squat rack for curls is considered bad etiquette in public gyms.
B-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff initially placed it in C+ tier but bumped it up to B-tier due to its high accessibility.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Perform curls with the bench angle completely horizontal, similar to a preacher curl setup.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Causes the highest bicep tension in the most stretched position. Good as a high-rep burnout with a really big stretch emphasis.
B-Tier.limitations: Tension drops off throughout the positive phase. Progression is limited to light weights and high reps, making it difficult to consistently add weight or reps over time.
B-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff used these as a high-rep finisher for a while but found himself gravitating back toward the standard 45-degree preacher curl because progression hit a wall quickly.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Requires only your own body weight and a pull-up bar.
B-Tier.execution_notes: From a side angle, a solid range of motion at the elbow joint is visible.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Will grow your biceps, especially for beginners, due to the significant elbow flexion involved. Highly accessible as it only requires body weight.
B-Tier.limitations: Because so much of your back musculature is also involved, it is unlikely that your biceps will be the limiting factor, making it less effective for bicep isolation compared to dedicated isolation exercises.
B-Tier.additional_notes: Out of all back exercises, Jeff believes chin-ups will grow your biceps the most.

C-Tier.setup_notes: A preacher curl performed with a vertical arm position.
C-Tier.tier_reasons: By placing your arm vertically, all tension in the stretched position is removed, making it a worse version of the 45-degree preacher curl.
C-Tier.limitations: Removes tension in the stretched position.
C-Tier.additional_notes: Despite being named after a bodybuilder with impressive biceps, Jeff does not consider it the best biceps exercise.

C-Tier.execution_notes: Move your arm back as you curl.
C-Tier.tier_reasons: While moving the arm back puts the bicep under a greater degree of stretch, simultaneously shortening the bicep at the elbow joint and lengthening it at the shoulder joint means the total biceps muscle length does not change much throughout the range of motion. This suggests it would not grow the biceps as well as a more standard dumbbell curl.
C-Tier.limitations: Total biceps muscle length does not change significantly throughout the range of motion.
C-Tier.scientific_insights: The biomechanics are similar to how the total hamstrings muscle length doesn't change much during a squat, and squats are known not to grow the hamstrings very well. Although there's no direct science on drag curls, this analogy suggests similar limitations.

C-Tier.setup_notes: Shift your arms forward in front of your body.
C-Tier.tier_reasons: By positioning the arms forward, the biceps are placed in a very shortened position, meaning they will not experience a high degree of stretch at any point in the range of motion.
C-Tier.limitations: Biceps are in a shortened position, lacking a high degree of stretch. Dumbbells can annoyingly hit the bench, disrupting the movement.
C-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff considers this an overrated exercise.

C-Tier.execution_notes: Perform seven reps in the bottom half of the range of motion, followed by seven reps in the top half, and then finish with seven full range of motion reps.
C-Tier.tier_reasons: The order of reps is suboptimal: it starts with the lengthened part (most anabolic), then moves to the shortened part (least anabolic), and finishes with full range of motion. This order is not ideal for maximizing muscle growth.
C-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Emphasizes both lengthened and shortened positions, but in a suboptimal order.
C-Tier.limitations: Suboptimal order of rep ranges for muscle growth.
C-Tier.alternative_options: Modified 21s (A-tier), which uses a more effective rep order.
C-Tier.additional_notes: Considered a 'bro exercise' and a fun way to challenge the arms, but not optimally structured.

F-Tier.tier_reasons: Considered gimmicky. It cranks the wrists, the plate feels awkward to hold, and it offers limited potential for progressive overload.
F-Tier.limitations: Causes wrist discomfort, awkward plate handling, limited overload potential.
F-Tier.alternative_options: Using dumbbells instead, which offers more degrees of freedom and still allows for hyperextending the wrists if desired.
F-Tier.additional_notes: Jeff considers this the worst of the worst bicep exercises.

criterias.High Tension in Stretched Position: Exercise provides significant tension, especially when the muscle is in its most lengthened state.

criterias.Feels Good: Exercise does not cause elbow pain and has a smooth, consistent resistance profile throughout the movement.

criterias.Simple Progression: Exercise allows for easy and consistent increases in weight or repetitions over time, which is crucial for long-term muscle growth.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Biceps Short Head: Sits on the inside of the arm.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Biceps Long Head: Sits on the back of the arm and contributes more to the 'biceps peak'.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Brachialis: A large muscle located underneath the biceps, as big as both biceps heads combined. It helps push the biceps up, creating bigger peaks.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Elbow Flexion: The primary function of the biceps, involving bending the elbow.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Supination: The action of turning the palm to face upwards, which actively contracts the biceps. The cue for this is 'driving through the pinkies'.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Shoulder Joint Crossing: Both heads of the biceps cross the shoulder joint, meaning the biceps are more stretched when the arm is held back behind the torso.

main_knowledge_summary.form_details: Different grips and angles significantly impact biceps activation and tension profiles. A **straight barbell** uses a fully supinated grip, which can strain wrists. The **Easy Bar** offers an angled grip, between fully supinated and neutral, which may shift tension to the brachialis/brachioradialis; to ensure biceps activation, 'drive through the pinkies' during the curl. A **neutral grip** (thumb up, as in hammer curls) takes the biceps out of supination, increasing brachialis activation. For **standing curls** (barbell, dumbbell, easy bar), tension is zero at full stretch and highest at 90° elbow flexion. **Preacher curls** (especially at 45°) angle the upper arm, pulling more tension into the biceps in the stretched position, locking the elbows to prevent cheating. **Incline curls** provide a large stretch with the arm held back, but often lack tension in that stretched position. **Lying dumbbell curls** are an extreme version of incline curls, offering a huge stretch near the shoulder and more tension in the stretched position than standard incline curls. The **Scott curl** (vertical arm) removes all tension in the stretched position. **Flat bench curls** (horizontal bench) create the highest bicep tension in the most stretched position, with tension dropping off later in the movement. **Machine preacher curls** offer a locked-in movement, allowing emphasis on the bottom half for stretch. **Drag curls** involve moving the arm back to increase biceps stretch, but simultaneous shortening at the elbow and lengthening at the shoulder means total biceps length changes minimally. **Spider curls** position the arms forward, placing the biceps in a shortened position without a high degree of stretch. **Face away cable curls** involve facing away from the cable with arms behind the torso, maximizing biceps stretch and providing even tension throughout the range; set the cable at hand height and take 1-2 steps forward. A **'freaky looking variation' cable curl** achieves a 90° angle between the cable and forearm when the bicep is most stretched, maximizing tension in the stretched position. **Strict curls** require bracing against a wall with glutes, upper back, and head to maintain strict technique and direct all tension to the biceps. **Cheating curls** involve using slight momentum to lift heavier loads, then controlling the negative phase.
main_knowledge_summary.training_keys: To maximize biceps growth, prioritize exercises that provide high tension in the stretched position, such as preacher curls and face away cable curls. While some exercises have suboptimal tension at full stretch, consistent effort through the full range of motion is still beneficial. For developing the 'biceps peak,' focus on exercises that put the long head of the biceps under high stretch and tension (e.g., face away cable curls) and incorporate hammer curls to target the brachialis, which can push the biceps up. Working each arm individually with dumbbells can help correct size asymmetries. Avoid long pauses without tension between repetitions, as this may be less optimal for muscle growth. Consider a modified approach to 21s: start with shortened range, then full ROM, and finish with lengthened partials to maximize effort as muscles fatigue. For experienced trainees, controlled cheating curls can be used to lift heavier loads and emphasize the anabolic negative phase, but strict curls are excellent for ensuring all tension is directed to the biceps and for tracking direct strength progression. The Face Away Cable Curl and 45° Preacher Curl are highly recommended for any biceps routine, while the Waiter Curl should be avoided.
main_knowledge_summary.research_insights: A new, unnamed study (referenced for another video) on full range of motion versus lengthened partials in experienced trainees suggests the importance of the tension curve, particularly in the stretched position. Research by Goto and colleagues indicates that long pauses without any tension between repetitions are likely detrimental to muscle growth. A recent study comparing incline curls to preacher curls found that preacher curls resulted in significantly more distal biceps growth (closer to the elbow). This is attributed to preacher curls providing high tension in a good stretch, whereas incline curls offer a large stretch with minimal tension. The presenter is planning to conduct a study comparing cheating versus strict form for muscle growth, as there is currently no definitive scientific evidence on this. While there's no hard science on directly changing biceps genetics or targeting the peak, the theoretical understanding that growing the brachialis can enhance biceps peak appearance is considered plausible.
main_knowledge_summary.optimization_notes: For consistent muscle growth, ensure progressive overload by regularly adding weight or reps. Incorporate a variety of exercises to target different aspects of biceps development, including stretch-biased movements and those that emphasize the brachialis. Machine preacher curls can be optimized by focusing on the bottom half of the range to enhance the stretch. Flat bench curls are effective as a high-rep finisher with a strong stretch emphasis, though progression may be limited to lighter weights. For advanced trainees, controlled cheating curls can be used to overload the negative phase, but beginners should prioritize strict form. Inverse Zottman curls are a smart pairing, leveraging hammer curls for brachialis activation on the positive phase and supinated curls for biceps overload on the stronger negative phase. The Face Away Cable Curl and 45° Preacher Curl are considered essential for an effective biceps routine. Avoid the Waiter Curl due to its awkwardness, wrist strain, and limited potential for overload.
